G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This action is brought in the Cambridge Division of the District Court Department of the Trial Court of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this action concerns a landlord-tenant dispute and damages arising from the rental of residential property.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: The lease includes, whether expressly or impliedly, a covenant of quiet enjoyment as mandated by G.L. c. 186, § 14, ensuring the tenant’s right to peaceful and undisturbed use and enjoyment of the premises.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Defendant failed to maintain the leased premises in a manner consistent with G.L. c. 239, § 8A, which permits tenants to raise breach of quiet enjoyment as a defense or affirmative claim in a landlord-tenant dispute.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every tenancy under Massachusetts law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to the tenants’ "implied covenant" or "implied warranty" of quiet enjoyment and treats that covenant as a given part of the landlord-tenant relationship, without suggesting it depends on express language in the lease. While the case focuses on constructive eviction and on when a landlord’s conduct breaches that covenant, its reasoning assumes—as an underlying premise—that such a covenant is implied in the tenancy. The court does not, however, expressly state in so many words that the covenant is implied in every tenancy, which slightly lowers confidence.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises “for a substantial time” (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a landlord’s failure to protect a tenant from foreseeable disruptions amounts to a constructive breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” language and, relying on common-law quiet enjoyment cases, holds that a landlord is liable where the natural and probable consequence of its conduct or omissions is interference with the tenant’s tenancy. The court emphasizes that malicious or specific intent is not required and that the statute covers at least reckless conduct, based on foreseeability of harm from unsanitary flooding conditions; this fits the idea that failure to protect a tenant from foreseeable disruptions can amount to a constructive breach of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The interference here is substantial and unreasonable, rendering the premises less suitable for its intended purpose—peaceful residential occupancy.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a statutory violation of the lead paint law, by itself, constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment; it does not discuss or apply any standard about the interference being ‘substantial and unreasonable’ or rendering premises less suitable for peaceful residential occupancy. Instead, it holds that at least negligent conduct and landlord notice are required to establish a § 14 violation, and it ultimately finds no quiet enjoyment liability here. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition about substantial and unreasonable interference with residential use.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.proposition: Defendant’s actions (and failure to act) are attributable to him as the property owner and principal who authorized or acquiesced in the disruptive renovation work.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.support_reasoning: The case concerns a public housing authority’s liability for failing to act against criminal drug activity by third parties on common areas, primarily in the context of statutory duties and the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not involve disruptive renovation work, nor does it discuss attributing contractors’ or agents’ renovation activities to a property owner or principal who authorized or acquiesced in such work. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about a defendant’s responsibility as owner/principal for disruptive renovation actions or omissions.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Winthrop Garage Co. v. Weinstein, 329 Ma.raw_text: Winthrop Garage Co. v. Weinstein, 329 Mass. 270 (1952)
Winthrop Garage Co. v. Weinstein, 329 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated the statutory covenant set forth in G.L. c. 186, § 14, as well as the common-law duty recognized by Massachusetts courts.
Winthrop Garage Co. v. Weinstein, 329 Ma.case_name: Massachusetts Bonding & Insurance v. Commissioner of Insurance
Winthrop Garage Co. v. Weinstein, 329 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is an insurance-rate regulation case about the Commissioner of Insurance’s authority under G.L. c. 175, § 113B and the scope of judicial review; it does not concern landlord–tenant law, interference with quiet enjoyment, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. There is no discussion of any statutory covenant under chapter 186 or of a common-law duty related to that statute, so the case cannot be authority for the proposition claimed.
Winthrop Garage Co. v. Weinstein, 329 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The pertinent provisions of § 113B are: ‘The commissioner shall, . . . after due hearing and investigation, fix and establish fair and reasonable classifications of risks and adequate, just, reasonable and non-discriminatory premium charges to be used and charged by companies in connection with the issue or execution of motor vehicle liability policies or bonds ....’ … Our conclusion, therefore, is that it is not incumbent upon the petitioners to allege that the premium charges will be confiscatory as to any company in order to obtain judicial review of the commissioner’s order.”

McAllister v. Boston Housing Authority,.raw_text: McAllister v. Boston Housing Authority, 429 Mass. 300 (1999)
McAllister v. Boston Housing Authority,.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to damages for loss of enjoyment, mental distress, and interference with her quiet possession.
McAllister v. Boston Housing Authority,.support_reasoning: The case does not hold that the plaintiff is entitled to damages for loss of enjoyment, mental distress, or interference with quiet possession. Instead, the court affirms a defense verdict, explicitly rejecting the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment and lease-based theories because negligence was not proven, and upholds a directed verdict on the implied warranty of habitability claim. The decision thus denies, rather than affirms, any entitlement to such damages on these facts.
McAllister v. Boston Housing Authority,.relevant_excerpt: We reject the plaintiff’s contention that she is entitled to a new trial based on her claims that the defendant violated the lease and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, G. L. c. 186, § 14. Negligence is a prerequisite for recovery under both theories. … The jury’s determination that the defendant was not negligent precludes the possibility that the directed verdicts on these claims constitute a basis for a new trial.

Shapiro v. Grinspoon, 27 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Shapiro v. Grinspoon, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 596 (1989)
Shapiro v. Grinspoon, 27 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to damages for loss of enjoyment, mental distress, and interference with her quiet possession.
Shapiro v. Grinspoon, 27 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case concerns return of a deposit in a failed commercial real estate purchase and the enforceability of a liquidated damages clause. It does not discuss or award damages for loss of enjoyment, mental distress, or interference with quiet possession; those concepts are not part of the issues, analysis, or remedy. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that a plaintiff is entitled to such damages.
Shapiro v. Grinspoon, 27 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Paragraph 12 of the purchase and sale agreement between the plaintiffs and defendants provided that, on default of the plaintiffs, “the deposits and accrued interest thereon shall be retained by [the defendants] and forfeited by [the plaintiffs] as liquidated damages in lieu of all other rights and remedies which [the defendants] may have against [the plaintiffs] at law or in equity. ...” Under this provision, the defendants laid claim to the $500,000 in deposits made by the plaintiffs and the accrued interest.

Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.raw_text: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512 (2003)
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.proposition: Plaintiff’s right to peaceful use was further recognized in Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512 (2003), emphasizing that landlord-controlled disturbances may breach the statutory covenant even without ill intent.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.case_name: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.support_reasoning: The opinion in Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy is about whether counterclaims are procedurally available in commercial summary process actions and whether G.L. c. 239, § 8A extends to commercial tenancies. It does not discuss a tenant’s right to peaceful use or quiet enjoyment, landlord-controlled disturbances, or breach of the statutory covenant absent ill intent. The proposition misattributes a substantive quiet enjoyment principle to a case that instead resolves a narrow procedural/statutory issue.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 239, § 8A, which creates a right to file counterclaims in summary process proceedings, states in pertinent part, ‘[i]n any action under this chapter to recover possession of any premises rented or leased for dwelling purposes… the tenant or occupant shall be entitled to raise, by defense or counterclaim, any claim against the plaintiff…’ (emphasis added). Because a tenant’s right to bring a counterclaim is explicitly limited in § 8A to premises ‘rented or leased for dwelling purposes,’ it is clear that it applies only to summary process actions in residential cases.”
